titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Flow Fund Circle records FA770

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-03-11 00:29:30 -0400.

did.unittitle: Flow Fund Circle records

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Flow Fund Circle records were donated to the RAC by Marion Rockefeller Weber in 2010. All records were transferred as Accession 2010:039.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC has legal title, copyright and literary rights to the records in so far as it holds them, and may grant permission to publish.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Special Formats (video, digital media, and photographic material) have been separated from the body of the collection to facilitate stabilization, migration, and long-term preservation. All pertinent items are assigned a unique separation number, as noted. Requests to access open special formats should reference the unique separation number.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Flow Fund Circle was founded in May 1991 by Marion Rockefeller Weber, daughter of Laurance S. Rockefeller and granddaughter of John D. Rockefeller Jr., as a non-traditional innovative approach to empower all people to become philanthropists and democratize the practice of philanthropy.

The FFC uses visionary creative thinking to identify and distribute funding to those in need through grassroots organic interactions with no overhead and minimal bureaucracy. The Flow Fund Circle began with five members and has expanded to more than 50.

Each Flow Fund Circle is seeded by a Donor, sometimes referred to as a Flow Fund Initiator. For example the Initiator may provide $20,000 per year for three years to a small group of individual Flow Funders. Each Flow Funder in turn can then donate their allotment to charities or organizations, in areas they identify, as they see fit. Flow Funders are advised not to donate all their resources to one project or one organization, and in turn cannot use the funding to finance their own projects. The average gift generally ranges from $250 to $2,500.

In some cases, the Donor or Initiator may seed their funds to a small group of Flow Fund Holders or Participants, and then the Holders serve to identify Flow Funders who then individually distribute the funds to charities. Flow Fund Holders or Participants are often former Flow Funders.

With Flow Funding grantees are awarded pure donations, with no prior project proposal or application process.Each year, Flow Funders submit reports documenting their giving, and meet to discuss their projects and experiences. The format and content of these reports is often as varied as the selection choices made. And the discussions and experiences help to shape the process itself as an ever evolving organism. Well over 500 grants have been made by members of the Flow Fund Circle to recipients in 45 countries, including 41 underdeveloped countries, since its inception in 1991 through the period covered by the collection.

The expansive and diverse areas of support include, but are not limited to: Advocacy, the Aged, Agriculture, Arts, Biodiversity, Children and Teens, Cultural Preservation, Disability, Disaster Relief, Ecology and Sustainability, Economic Development, Education, Health, Job Training, Media, Micro-Enterprise, Nuclear Power, Peace, Poverty, Refugees, Rehabilitation, Spirituality, Sport, Water and Women's issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes Flow Fund reports, financial reports, correspondence, testimonials, and a variety of associated audio-visual and digital media. Still images documenting the experience are often an itegral part of the Flow Fund reports.
